data.title: A tour of Modernista Barcelona
data.meta_description: Look at this building. Just look at it. Is there any city, anywhere in the world, whose key architecture is so magical, so otherwordly, so redolent of a time and a place? That’s a rhetorical…
data.text:
Jez Torrance

·

Follow

5 min read

·

Nov 28, 2023

--

Look at this building. Just look at it. Is there any city, anywhere in the world, whose key architecture is so magical, so otherwordly, so redolent of a time and a place? That’s a rhetorical question, by the way.

Barcelona is undoubtedly Antoni Gaudí’s city. He is the Modernista master.

Thirty-odd million tourists visit Barcelona a year. Probably 90% of them completely fall in love with Antoni Gaudí’s architecture. I did. (The other 10% are most likely blind-drunk stag do attendees.)

Architecture is so much more than beautiful building, it’s the history of a city in stone and wood. To really get to know a city you devour its architecture. To really get to know Barcelona you devour Gaudí’s buildings.

Which is what I did in Sep 2017…

I started here, a list of Gracia’s modernista buildings.

Gracía may well have more modernista structures per square meter than any other place on earth.

This was handy. Gracía was where we were based. My completist, list-ticking alter ego kicked in. I made a list of all the city’s modernista buildings (or rather stole it from Wikipedia), plotted them on a map (which you can see here or below) and set out to conquer them all.

(The titles of the buildings link to their location. All the photos were taken by me. They are of substandard quality — feel free to use but probably unwise to. These, on the other hand, are mostly lovely.)

1. Casa Vicens

5. La Casa Comalat

Hmmm — must have missed this. Note to self: more haste, less speed.

6. Casa de les Punxes

12. Casa Calvet

Another I appeared to have missed.

13. Camiseria Bonet

14. Cafè de l’Òpera

15. Lampposts in Plaça Reial

20. Park Güell

Reportedly on one occasion Gaudí said to Güell, “Sometimes I think we are the only people who like this architecture.” Güell replied, “I don’t like your architecture, I respect it.”

Well, I love and respect this architecture. Goodbye.

Antoni Gaudí: bringing heaven to earth

Traffic had stopped, shops were shut and paving stones were being uprooted to build barricades. Up on a roof a British…
